139.author: Robert Hahn
139.bottom_line: You are most likely to trigger an avalanche on a wind-loaded slope, including shallow slabs or potentially a very large and destructive persistent slab. We have significant uncertainty about the weak snow above the mid-January crust.  Consider reducing your exposure to large slopes steeper than 35 degrees.
139.hazard_discussion:
Thursday night's storm brought some light to moderate winds, but hardly any precipitation.  

On Thursday, NWAC and NPS professionals reported 35 inches of "right-side-up" or increasing density snow above the decomposing mid-January crust.  The observers noted a significant and widespread avalanche cycle on N aspect slopes from heavy snowfall January 31 - Feb 2.  Crowns were particularly prevalent on N-NE aspects where almost every steep, convex rollover produced an avalanche. Many were small, but some were large. Their investigation of two crowns on NE aspects at 5100 ft showed that the slide had propagated in the old snow on top of the mid-January crust.  All natural avalanche activity occurred during the storm. It is unknown whether the slides initiated on near-surface facets just above the crust or on surface hoar a few inches higher. 

Some aspects could still be close to the tipping point, but just waiting for a trigger. This uncertainty warrants increased caution and a greater margin for safety on Saturday.

2020-21 Forecast Schedule: Avalanche danger ratings will be issued for the Olympics every Friday through Sunday and during mid-week holidays. During the week when the Hurricane Ridge road is closed, forecast information will be updated daily to include expected conditions and relevant travel advice under the No Rating label.

During the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, continue to follow the latest guidance from local, state, and federal health officials. Avoid unnecessary risks that could impact first responders and stress medical resources.  Wear a mask when appropriate, practice social distancing, and consider recreating closer to home.

media.caption: (2/4/2021) Persistent slab avalanche that likely failed naturally during a recent storm cycle. Hurricane Ridge Road in the foreground. Photo: Sam Luthy
(2/4/2021) 1/13 crust with rounding surface hoar layer above. Photo: Sam Luthy
Surface hoar layer with several inches above the mid-January crust. Photo: Sam Luthy.
(2/4/2021) Persistent Slab crown profile. Photo: Sam Luthy

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: If the forecasted shallow snow and wind materialize, wind slabs will become dangerous above treeline by the end of the day. Focus on several inches of new snow falling and drifting with moderate W winds Friday night and Saturday. Wind slabs should be small and relatively shallow near treeline, confined to specific terrain features such as just below freshly corniced ridgelines. Above treeline, they will become slightly larger, more widespread, and difficult to steer around. Avoid slopes with active wind loading. Check the direction of fresh sharp cornices and wind lips, rime plastered on trees, and snow stripped from trees. Steer around recently wind-loaded terrain features near treeline and avoid all slopes steeper than 35 degrees above treeline.

media.caption: Example of wind-affected snow below corniced ridgelines where you are more likely to trigger a wind slab avalanche. Photo: Ethan Taylor

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wind Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wind Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) formed by the wind. Wind typically transports snow from the upwind sides of terrain features and deposits snow on the downwind side. Wind slabs are often smooth and rounded and sometimes sound hollow, and can range from soft to hard. Wind slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: Several layers of weak snow lurk above the mid-January crusts, including facets and surface hoar. Persistent weak layers are true to their name: they persist. If you trigger one, it will propagate widely. You'll find the weak interface about 35 inches down, within the range of human trigger. Wind slab or cornice fall avalanches may be the most likely triggers on Saturday.  Any avalanche on either weak layer will be large to very large and difficult to survive. Although snowpack test results were not impressive, similar layers of rounding facets and surface hoar in the Cascades have produced numerous avalanches in recent days, some of them human-triggered. Given our uncertainty surrounding this layer, we suggest continuing to dial back your terrain selection. Reduce your exposure to large avalanche slopes 35 degrees and steeper.

media.caption: (1/30/2021) Human triggered persistent slab avalanche stepping down to 1/13 crust.  Estimated to be size D1.5. North facing aspect near Victoria Overlook.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Persistent Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Persistent Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) in the middle to upper snowpack, when the bond to an underlying persistent weak layer breaks. Persistent layers include: surface hoar, depth hoar, near-surface facets, or faceted snow. Persistent weak layers can continue to produce avalanches for days, weeks or even months, making them especially dangerous and tricky. As additional snow and wind events build a thicker slab on top of the persistent weak layer, this avalanche problem may develop into a Deep Persistent Slab.

140.author: Matt Primomo
140.bottom_line: Heavy snow and strong winds are expected to tip the scales and create a natural avalanche cycle. Very dangerous avalanche conditions are expected to peak Saturday afternoon, so travel into places where avalanches can start, run, and stop is strongly advised against. You could easily trigger deep and destructive avalanches on an old, slick crust.
140.hazard_discussion:
Josh Hirshberg reported a natural, 1,000+ft wide D2.5 persistent slab in Highlands Bowl (SE at 5,600ft) on Friday. Professional guides reported huge collapses (whumphs) below Skyline Lake. Ski Patrol at the pass remotely triggered 2ft deep avalanches while skinning on a ridgeline. These were on northeast aspects at 5,800ft and ran on the crust from 1/13. WSDOT triggered large avalanches in both new snow, and older snow early in the morning as well. One was a D3 avalanche (big enough to destroy some trees) and ran on the crust as well. These are the first confirmed avalanches on this layer that we have in the zone, and they are certainly not the last. 

The next round of snowfall should continue the current avalanche cycle, and we could see some defined avalanche paths run close to their full potential on Saturday into Saturday night. During the week, we observed sudden, planer, and often easy failures with snowpit tests in the upper pack. Others reported spooky collapsing. Even in some areas below treeline, we can't write off the chances for slabs to run on this deeper layer.

During the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, continue to follow the latest guidance from local, state, and federal health officials. Avoid unnecessary risks that could impact first responders and stress medical resources.  Wear a mask when appropriate, practice social distancing, and consider recreating closer to home.

media.caption: (2/3/2021) This crack came from a whumph we heard while stepping on a thick wind pillow. It fractured on the slick 1/13 crust, about 1.5ft deep.
(2/3/2021) Clean, easy tilt test results below a recent crust. South aspect at 5,000ft on Lichtenberg.
(2/3/2021) Small rounded facets on a 2 and 3mm grid, found down 15" on south aspect at 5,000ft on Lichtenberg. Test results indicated sudden, clean failures, and the ability for propagation.

(2/3/2021) A person touring along the ridgeline from Artist Point to Huntoon Point remotely triggered a cornice that fell onto the slope below triggering this large avalanche.  The avalanche occurred on a NE aspect at 5000ft and failed about 1 meter deep on the 1/24 interface.

I travelled to the Lanham Lake area on Sunday. This pit profile photo is representative of many hasty pits that I dug in the area. The uppermost crust from Jan 24 had a thin layer of facets above it in some areas. Where those facets were present failures occurred easily on that layer.
Long shooting cracks are indicators of unstable snow surfaces, which may avalanche if the slope is steep enough.
Skier triggered wind slab avalanches are possible at higher elevations on Wednesday.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: Heavy snow and strong wind will continue to tip the snowpack to its breaking point on Saturday, and you could trigger deep, wide and surprising avalanches. On Friday, a number of large and wide natural, and human-triggered avalanches ran on weak snow over the crust from mid-January. Some were triggered from a distance by skiers walking on a ridgeline or in adjacent terrain with huge whumphs reported. On Saturday, these could be 3ft+ deep and could be triggered from a distance or from below on connected slopes. Some slopes may have the ability to create these large and surprising avalanches, while other ones may not. The tricky part is that it will be very difficult to tell, and it's not worth betting your life on it. When the snowpack is this complex, keep your terrain choices simple and stay out of avalanche terrain. Elevations below 4,500ft may offer lower chances of triggering one of these.

media.caption: (2/5/2021) This avalanche was remotely triggered in backcountry terrain just outside of the Crystal ski area. Similar to other recent slides, it failed on facets just above the 1/13 crust. 60cm deep, 150' wide. 5200' ESE aspect. Photo: Crystal Mt Ski Patrol

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Persistent Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Persistent Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) in the middle to upper snowpack, when the bond to an underlying persistent weak layer breaks. Persistent layers include: surface hoar, depth hoar, near-surface facets, or faceted snow. Persistent weak layers can continue to produce avalanches for days, weeks or even months, making them especially dangerous and tricky. As additional snow and wind events build a thicker slab on top of the persistent weak layer, this avalanche problem may develop into a Deep Persistent Slab.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: Heavy snowfall along with fluctuating temperatures and very strong wind are expected. It doesn't take a rocket scientist to tell us that conditions will be prime for avalanches on Saturday. Stay aware as you travel through snow and take notice if you see shooting cracks or recent soft avalanches. The new snow will sit over a variety of weak surfaces and older weak layers. Any small avalanche in the new snow could step down to be deeper and surprising avalanches. Strong wind will also redistribute snow in exposed terrain and create wind slabs, even below treeline. For these reasons, avoid slopes that are steeper than 30 degrees and stay out from underneath avalanche terrain.

media.caption: Example storm slab on a small test slope.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Storm Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Storm Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer (a slab) of new snow that breaks within new snow or on the old snow surface. Storm-slabs typically last between a few hours and few days (following snowfall). Storm-slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

141.author: Andy Harrington
141.bottom_line: Another round of heavy snow and strong winds will maintain very dangerous avalanche conditions at Snoqualmie Pass on Saturday. A weak snowpack will make managing terrain more difficult than you may be used to. Let the storm run its course by keeping away from all avalanche terrain.
141.hazard_discussion:
Saturday should be a similar storm as Thursday night at Snoqualmie Pass, except lower freezing levels are expected and the bulk of the precipitation should come during the daylight hours, increasing the hazard throughout the day. On Friday, Alpental Patrol reported slabs as deep as 3 feet triggered during control work above the rain/snow line, while wet avalanches were triggered at lower elevations. Professionals in the Kendall area were able to verify the existence of our layers of concern and weak snow grains, which are driving the Persistent Slab problem. The two layers we are most concerned with are the 2/1 crust, which has weak snow above and below it. And the Mid-January Crust (1/13), which contains weak snow above it. Although these weak snow grains have shown signs of healing in recent days, they have also been the point of failure for multiple small avalanches. 

As we continue to receive new snow and wind, slab depth atop these weak layers will increase. Slopes that have reached their tipping point already could reload and produce another round of avalanches. More concerning may be slopes that have not yet reached their tipping point.  Saturday's storm could be enough to finally tip the scales, producing large and deadly avalanches. Recent avalanches, persistent grains in the snowpack, strong winds, and heavy snow are all red flags informing you that the snowpack is unstable and needs time to heal. Continue to exercise patience and caution as this storm cycle plays out.

During the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, continue to follow the latest guidance from local, state, and federal health officials. Avoid unnecessary risks that could impact first responders and stress medical resources.  Wear a mask when appropriate, practice social distancing, and consider recreating closer to home.

media.caption: (2/4/2021) This thin slab failed just above the 2/1 crust in the Alpental Valley on Thursday (02/04). It was one of many small avalanches observed in the area. Photo Joe Hoch

(2/3/2021) This snow profiles shows a similar snowpack structure to other areas in the zone. The 1/13 crust sits about 25-30cm below the surface. The 2/1 crust failed in several tests with small facets underneath. However, at the moment, it' very shallow.
(2/3/2021) These 1mm facets were sampled from just above the 1/13 crust. While they show signs of rounding, they remain very weak and failed in several snowpack tests. NE 4800', Keechelus Ridge.
(1/31/2021) Pit from the Kendall slide paths on Sunday 1/31
(1/31/2021) This slab was triggered by a skier in the Alpental Valley on Sunday 1/31.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: Observations from Snoqualmie Pass on Friday continue to find a weak snowpack structure within the zone which may produce larger, deeper, and surprising avalanches on Saturday. There are currently two crusts within the snowpack that have weak snow grains sitting above or below them. With continued high precipitation rates on Saturday and more load added to stress these layers, avalanches could trigger remotely or propagate widely either naturally or by human trigger. Stay away from all terrain where avalanches can start, run, or stop.

media.caption: (2/4/2021) This thin avalanche failed just above the 2/1 crust layer in the Snow Lake Divide area of Snoqualmie Pass. Similar natural and human triggered slides were reported by several professionals at Snoqualmie Pass. Photo Renne Shapiro.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Persistent Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Persistent Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) in the middle to upper snowpack, when the bond to an underlying persistent weak layer breaks. Persistent layers include: surface hoar, depth hoar, near-surface facets, or faceted snow. Persistent weak layers can continue to produce avalanches for days, weeks or even months, making them especially dangerous and tricky. As additional snow and wind events build a thicker slab on top of the persistent weak layer, this avalanche problem may develop into a Deep Persistent Slab.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: If we didn’t have an existing weak snowpack, this storm would still be capable of creating plenty of avalanches. Snowfall is expected to increase throughout the day with a slight bit of warming in the afternoon hours. These fluctuating snow levels combined with strong winds should create multiple potential weak interfaces in the recent storm snow. Any avalanche failing on these layers could act as a trigger for those deeper persistent slabs. Even if you suspect that a persistent issue does not exist in your area, you should stay out of avalanche terrain as this storm runs its course.

media.caption: (1/31/2021) This Wind Slab was intentionally triggered on a wind-loaded convexity in the Kendall area last weekend. The slab initially broke on a density change before stepping down and failing on the 1/13 crust. Similar activity is expected this weekend with much thicker slabs.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Storm Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Storm Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer (a slab) of new snow that breaks within new snow or on the old snow surface. Storm-slabs typically last between a few hours and few days (following snowfall). Storm-slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

142.author: Andrew Kiefer
142.bottom_line: Unusual and very dangerous avalanche conditions exist. Additional loading from new snow and wind will only make matters worse on Saturday. Weak layers deep in the snowpack may continue to produce destructive and unsurvivable avalanches. Avoid open slopes 30 degrees and steeper and stay far away from avalanche path runout zones.
142.hazard_discussion:
The past two weeks were very active in the West North zone with impressive storms, eye-opening avalanche cycles, and a few close calls. Avalanche conditions related to new snow and wind are concerning enough, and a lingering deep slab instability poses uncertainty and high consequences. Avoid avalanche terrain Saturday and be patient while the snowpack takes time to adjust and stabilize.  

Beginning January 24, incremental loads of light snowfall buried a weak old snow surface (mid-January crust/facets) that formed during a prolonged period of cold, clear weather. Observations January 25-29 indicated the old snow surface to be problematic in isolated areas, but avalanches within new and wind drifted snow were more widespread. Heavy loading from new snow and wind January 30 - February 2 (4ft of snow/8.5in water at Heather Meadows) finally pushed the mid-January crust/facets to a tipping point and caused a natural cycle of deep slab avalanches large enough to destroy a house or break mature trees. With clear skies on February 3, many long time locals and professionals were able to document the aftermath, reporting avalanches in areas they had never seen run, and avalanche paths producing slides larger than they can remember. Several close calls also occurred including snowmobile triggered avalanches breaking 3ft+ thick and several hundred feet wide in Canyon Creek on February 3 (photo below), and very large natural avalanches on February 1 on Mt. Herman's east face hitting Bagley Creek with debris and powder clouds running uphill across the valley towards nearby skiers (video below). 

During the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, continue to follow the latest guidance from local, state, and federal health officials. Avoid unnecessary risks that could impact first responders and stress medical resources.  Wear a mask when appropriate, practice social distancing, and consider recreating closer to home.

media.caption: (2/4/2021) The crown of a natural deep persistent slab avalanche that failed on the mid-January crust/facets. The avalanche occurred on a SW aspect of Mt. Herman near 5000ft. Photo: Simon Trautman

(1/2/2021) Observers on February 1 captured video of two large natural avalanches on the east aspect of Mt. Herman. Both avalanches crossed high traffic routes along Bagley Creek, just a few hundred yards away from the Heather Meadows parking area.

(2/3/2021) A snowmobile triggered avalanche (D2) in the Excelsior area of Canyon Creek Wednesday. The avalanche occurred on a NW aspect at 5400ft and failed 3-4ft deep on the mid-January crust/facets.
(2/3/2021) A person touring along the ridgeline from Artist Point to Huntoon Point remotely triggered a cornice that fell onto the slope below triggering this large avalanche (NE, 5000ft).
(2/4/2021) The crown of a recent natural avalanche (D3) on the south aspect of Mt. Herman near 5600ft. The ski pole points to the weak layer. Photo: Simon Trautman
Very large avalanches broke several feet thick and propagated long distances during the January 30 - February 2 storm. Photo: Mt Baker Ski Patrol
(2/3/2021) Crowns of recent very large natural avalanches on Video Peak/Happy Bunny Butte on northerly aspects between 5200-5400ft.
(2/3/2021) Very large natural avalanches on the S and W aspects of Bacon Peak.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: Expect another foot of new snow to accumulate above 3000ft during the day Saturday. Peak instability will likely coincide with the heaviest precipitation rates which look to occur in the afternoon. Natural avalanches due to new snow and wind could grow large, and could even trigger deeper layers in the snowpack as they run downslope resulting in very destructive avalanches. Recent observations indicate a poor bond at the old/new snow interface buried Thursday, and natural and triggered avalanches 6-24in deep propagated widely across terrain features Friday. The problem will only get worse with additional loading over the next 24 hours. Avoid all steep open slopes, and seek out simple terrain away from overhead hazard.

media.caption: (2/5/2021) Storm slab avalanche on a northerly aspect near 4800ft outside of the Mt. Baker Ski Area. The avalanche failed 6-8in deep with wide propagation. Photo: Pete Durr, USFS Backcountry Ranger

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Storm Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Storm Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer (a slab) of new snow that breaks within new snow or on the old snow surface. Storm-slabs typically last between a few hours and few days (following snowfall). Storm-slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
A widespread natural avalanche cycle occurred during the storm January 30 - February 2. Numerous avalanches broke 3-4ft+ deep on a weak layer above a prominent crust (mid-January crust/facets). Avalanches grew very large (D3), had wide propagation wrapping terrain features, and ran far distances hitting valley bottoms. A handful of avalanches were human triggered on this layer Wednesday. Additional loading from new snow and wind will continue to test this layer and may produce another round of destructive avalanches.

The potential for natural and triggered deep persistent slab avalanches exists above 4000-4500ft on slopes 30 degrees and steeper. This is not a problem to try to outsmart. These conditions are difficult to manage and tricky to accurately assess. You can use snow profiles and snowpack tests to track these layers, but not necessarily as decision-making tools. Build in a wide margin for error and stay away from steep open slopes.

media.caption: (2/3/2021) Very large avalanches ran naturally on Mt Herman during the storm cycle between January 31 and February 2.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Deep Persistent Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Deep Persistent Slab avalanches are the release of a thick cohesive layer of hard snow (a slab), when the bond breaks between the slab and an underlying persistent weak layer deep in the snowpack. The most common persistent weak layers involved in deep, persistent slabs are depth hoar or facets surrounding a deeply buried crust. Deep Persistent Slabs are typically hard to trigger, are very destructive and dangerous due to the large mass of snow involved, and can persist for months once developed. They are often triggered from areas where the snow is shallow and weak, and are particularly difficult to forecast for and manage.

143.author: Andrew Kiefer
143.bottom_line: Unusual and very dangerous avalanche conditions exist. Additional loading from new snow and wind will only make matters worse on Saturday. Weak layers deep in the snowpack may continue to produce destructive and unsurvivable avalanches. Avoid open slopes 30 degrees and steeper and stay far away from avalanche path runout zones.
143.hazard_discussion:
The past two weeks were very active throughout the region with impressive storms, eye-opening avalanche cycles, and a few close calls. Avalanche conditions related to new snow and wind are concerning enough, and a lingering deep slab instability poses uncertainty and high consequences. Avoid avalanche terrain Saturday and be patient while the snowpack takes time to adjust and stabilize.  

Beginning January 24, incremental loads of light snowfall buried a weak old snow surface (mid-January crust/facets) that formed during a prolonged period of cold, clear weather. Observations January 25-29 indicated the old snow surface to be problematic in isolated areas, but avalanches within new and wind drifted snow were more widespread. Heavy loading from new snow and wind January 30 - February 2 finally pushed the mid-January crust/facets to a tipping point and caused a natural cycle of deep slab avalanches large enough to destroy a house or break mature trees. With clear skies on February 3, many long time locals and professionals were able to document the aftermath, reporting avalanches in areas they had never seen run, and avalanche paths producing slides larger than they can remember. Several close calls also occurred in the West North zone including snowmobile triggered avalanches breaking 3ft+ thick and several hundred feet wide in Canyon Creek along Hwy 542 on February 3 (photo below), and very large natural avalanches on February 1 on Mt. Herman's east face hitting Bagley Creek with debris and powder clouds running uphill across the valley towards nearby skiers (video below). 

During the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, continue to follow the latest guidance from local, state, and federal health officials. Avoid unnecessary risks that could impact first responders and stress medical resources.  Wear a mask when appropriate, practice social distancing, and consider recreating closer to home.

media.caption: (2/4/2021) The crown of a natural deep persistent slab avalanche that failed on the mid-January crust/facets. The avalanche occurred on a SW aspect of Mt. Herman near 5000ft. Photo: Simon Trautman

(1/2/2021) Observers on February 1 captured video of two large natural avalanches on the east aspect of Mt. Herman. Both avalanches crossed high traffic routes along Bagley Creek, just a few hundred yards away from the Heather Meadows parking area.

(2/3/2021) A snowmobile triggered avalanche (D2) in the Excelsior area of Canyon Creek Wednesday. The avalanche occurred on a NW aspect at 5400ft and failed 3-4ft deep on the mid-January crust/facets.
(2/3/2021) A person touring along the ridgeline from Artist Point to Huntoon Point remotely triggered a cornice that fell onto the slope below triggering this large avalanche (NE, 5000ft).
(2/4/2021) The crown of a recent natural avalanche (D3) on the south aspect of Mt. Herman near 5600ft. The ski pole points to the weak layer. Photo: Simon Trautman
Very large avalanches broke several feet thick and propagated long distances during the January 30 - February 2 storm. Photo: Mt Baker Ski Patrol
(2/3/2021) Crowns of recent very large natural avalanches on Video Peak/Happy Bunny Butte on northerly aspects between 5200-5400ft.
(2/3/2021) Very large natural avalanches on the S and W aspects of Bacon Peak.

Peak instability will likely coincide with the heaviest precipitation rates which look to occur in the afternoon. Natural avalanches due to new snow and wind could grow large, and could even trigger deeper layers in the snowpack as they run downslope resulting in very destructive avalanches. Recent observations indicate a poor bond at the old/new snow interface buried Thursday, and natural and triggered avalanches 6-24in deep propagated widely across terrain features Friday. The problem will only get worse with additional loading over the next 24 hours. Avoid all steep open slopes, and seek out simple terrain away from overhead hazard.

media.caption: (2/5/2021) Storm slab avalanche on a northerly aspect near 4800ft outside of the Mt. Baker Ski Area. The avalanche failed 6-8in deep with wide propagation. Photo: Pete Durr, USFS Backcountry Ranger

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Storm Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Storm Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer (a slab) of new snow that breaks within new snow or on the old snow surface. Storm-slabs typically last between a few hours and few days (following snowfall). Storm-slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
A widespread natural avalanche cycle occurred in the adajcent West North zone during the storm January 30 - February 2. Numerous avalanches broke 3-4ft+ deep on a weak layer above a prominent crust (mid-January crust/facets). Avalanches grew very large (D3), had wide propagation wrapping terrain features, and ran far distances hitting valley bottoms. A handful of avalanches were human triggered on this layer Wednesday. Additional loading from new snow and wind will continue to test this layer and may produce another round of destructive avalanches.

The potential for natural and triggered deep persistent slab avalanches exists above 4000-4500ft on slopes 30 degrees and steeper. This is not a problem to try to outsmart. These conditions are difficult to manage and tricky to accurately assess. You can use snow profiles and snowpack tests to track these layers, but not necessarily as decision-making tools. Build in a wide margin for error and stay away from steep open slopes.

media.caption: (2/3/2021) Very large avalanches ran naturally on Mt Herman during the storm cycle between January 31 and February 2.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Deep Persistent Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Deep Persistent Slab avalanches are the release of a thick cohesive layer of hard snow (a slab), when the bond breaks between the slab and an underlying persistent weak layer deep in the snowpack. The most common persistent weak layers involved in deep, persistent slabs are depth hoar or facets surrounding a deeply buried crust. Deep Persistent Slabs are typically hard to trigger, are very destructive and dangerous due to the large mass of snow involved, and can persist for months once developed. They are often triggered from areas where the snow is shallow and weak, and are particularly difficult to forecast for and manage.

144.author: Andy Harrington
144.bottom_line: Very dangerous avalanche conditions are expected to continue on Saturday as new snow and strong winds load a weak snowpack. This weak snowpack has consistently produced avalanches for over a week and is not going to heal quickly. Let nature do its thing and stay out of all avalanche terrain.
144.hazard_discussion:
Unlike Thursday night’s storm, this storm should drop the bulk of its precipitation during the daylight hours on Saturday, increasing the hazard throughout the day. There are currently two layers of concern in the upper snowpack. The Mid-January Crust (1/13) contains weak snow grains on top of the crust and has been the culprit for much of the avalanche activity in the past week in areas such as Crystal, Mt. Saint Helens, and White Pass. This layer could be around 3-4 feet deep in some locations. The 2/1 crust is a bit closer to the surface and may be found closer to 2 feet down, with weak snow above and possibly below it. Although these weak snow grains have shown signs of healing in some locations, they have been the point of failure for avalanches all week long (up to size D2.5) and are very much in play. 

As we continue to receive new snow and wind, slab depth atop these weak layers will increase. Slopes that have reached their tipping point already could reload and produce another round of avalanches. More concerning may be slopes that have not yet reached their tipping point. Those slopes could finally reach that point on Saturday, producing large and deadly avalanches. Recent avalanches, persistent grains in the snowpack, strong winds, and heavy snow are all red flags informing you that the snowpack is unstable and needs time to heal. Continue to exercise patience and caution as this storm cycle plays out by staying away from avalanche terrain.

During the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, continue to follow the latest guidance from local, state, and federal health officials. Avoid unnecessary risks that could impact first responders and stress medical resources.  Wear a mask when appropriate, practice social distancing, and consider recreating closer to home.

media.caption: (2/5/2021) We don't know of any slides in the Paradise area yet, but the snowpack structure is there and similar to other areas of the zone where more widespread persistent activity has taken place.

(2/3/2021) This natural avalanche likely occurred overnight on 02/02. Similar to other slides it failed on facets above the 13 crust in non-skier compacted terrain of Crystal Mt. It occurred on a SE aspect at 6500'. Crown depth 2'. Photo: Crystal Mountain Ski Patrol

(2/3/2021) This natural avalanche likely occurred overnight on 02/02 in non-skier compacted terrain within Crystal Mt Ski Area. It failed on 1-2mm facets just above the 1/13 crust. 6300' NNE aspect. 85-95cm deep. Photo: Cyrstal Mt Ski Patrol
(2/1/2021) This small wind slab avalanche stepped down to the 1/23 facets above the thick prominent crust. Gunsight Bowl: N aspect, 6300',  18" crown. HS-ASc-D1.5-R2-O
(2/1/2021) This snow profile from Miriam creek near White Pass shows the facet layer of concern.

(1/29/2021) Multiple slabs were remotely triggered from a far distance by a snowmobiler on Mt. Saint Helens on Friday (1/29). There were multiple other slides remotely triggered and observed on the same day. [Photo: Kurt Heine]

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: Surprising avalanches have been easily triggered, propagated widely, and ran quickly in many areas of the West South this past week. Some of these slides were triggered from long distances away or stepped down into older, deeper layers of the snowpack. A weak snowpack structure has been observed throughout the zone, even in areas that have not yet produced these avalanches. There are currently two crusts within the snowpack that have weak snow grains sitting above or below them. With continued high precipitation rates on Saturday and more load added to stress these layers, we expect more of these scary and unpredictable avalanches to follow. Stay away from all terrain where avalanches can start, run, or stop.

media.caption: (2/5/2021) This avalanche was remotely triggered in backcountry terrain just outside of the Crystal ski area. Similar to other recent slides, it failed on facets just above the 1/13 crust. 60cm deep, 150' wide. 5200' ESE aspect. Photo: Crystal Mt Ski Patrol

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Persistent Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Persistent Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) in the middle to upper snowpack, when the bond to an underlying persistent weak layer breaks. Persistent layers include: surface hoar, depth hoar, near-surface facets, or faceted snow. Persistent weak layers can continue to produce avalanches for days, weeks or even months, making them especially dangerous and tricky. As additional snow and wind events build a thicker slab on top of the persistent weak layer, this avalanche problem may develop into a Deep Persistent Slab.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: If you took away the deeper instabilities and threw us back into what we perceive as normal Pacific Northwest conditions, this storm would still be capable of creating plenty of avalanches on Saturday. Snowfall is expected to increase throughout the day with a slight bit of warming in the afternoon hours. These fluctuating snow levels combined with strong winds should create multiple potential weak interfaces in the recent storm snow. Snowfall should be more significant on the volcanoes while winds should be more significant closer to the crest, creating a little variability. Regardless of where you find yourself, any avalanche failing on these layers could act as a trigger for those deeper persistent slabs. Even if you suspect that a persistent issue does not exist in your area, you should stay out of avalanche terrain as this storm runs its course.

media.caption: (2/5/2021) The upper snowpack contained multiple density breaks and "normal PNW" weaknesses above the persistent layers at Paradise on Thursday. There should be even more from Thursday night and Saturday's storms. Triggering one of these layers could cause slabs to step down to those deeper and scarier persistent layers.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Storm Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Storm Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer (a slab) of new snow that breaks within new snow or on the old snow surface. Storm-slabs typically last between a few hours and few days (following snowfall). Storm-slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

145.author: Matt Primomo
145.bottom_line: Another round of snowfall with very strong wind will create very dangerous avalanche conditions at upper elevations on Saturday. Large, and often surprising avalanches have been occurring and may be triggered on a variety of weak layers even below treeline. Consider avoiding entire features in avalanche terrain, and stay alert to signs of instability such as shooting cracks and whumphs.
145.hazard_discussion:
A large ski triggered avalanche was reported from the near treeline band on Friday, and folks reported several small wind slabs in steep terrain below cliff features in Cutthroat drainage. Professionals reported shooting cracks and propagation from steeper terrain as well. On Wednesday, strong sun appeared to have pushed the slopes in Portley Bowl over the edge and caused natural avalanches. This following a ski triggered slab in the bowl on Tuesday. A skier had a close call on Tuesday near an area often thought of as 'safe' ski terrain. We suspect buried surface hoar as the culprit for these past two avalanches.

Outside of wind-affected areas, you may find about 2ft of snow above the Jan 30th interface in the Washington Pass area. Another potential weak layer are small facets within, or above a crust from mid-January. This prominent crust can be found about 3ft below the surface at mid and lower elevations.

Further east in the zone, the weakened crust from mid-January has been a concern, even below treeline. Observers in the Twisp drainage reported collapsing at 4,800ft on a northeast aspect on Monday, and snowpack tests show potential for avalanches to propagate. Also on Monday, a large avalanche was heard in the Lost River drainage following a period of warming and light to moderate precipitation. To sum it up, we have higher uncertainty with the shallower and weaker snowpack in the eastern part of the zone. If you travel to areas such as the Chelan-Sawtooth Mountains, Twisp River, and Chewuch drainages, take time to dig in the snow and look for older weak layers. You'll need to evaluate the upper snowpack carefully to travel safely in avalanche terrain no matter where you go on Saturday!

During the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, continue to follow the latest guidance from local, state, and federal health officials. Avoid unnecessary risks that could impact first responders and stress medical resources. Wear a mask when appropriate, practice social distancing, and consider recreating closer to home.

media.caption: (2/2/2021) Ski triggered avalanche in Portley Bowl. East aspect at ~7,000ft
(1/31/2021) A profile from 5,700ft, SE in Cutthroat Creek. Photo: Josh Hirshberg

(1/31/2021) The darker stripe of snow is a layer of surface hoar buried on January 30th near Washington Pass. This was found 25cm below the surface on a SE aspect at 5,700ft on January 31st. Photo: Josh Hirshberg
(1/31/2021) About a foot of recent snow produced fast and clean shears on an interface of recent snow (DF) and surface hoar.  SE, 5,750ft, Cutthroat ck. Photo: Josh Hirshberg
(1/27/2021) Storm snow over a crust has been collapsing on weaker snow below. 5,500ft in the lower Methow drainage. Photo: Drew Lovell

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
Wide and surprising avalanches are possible if an avalanche runs on faceted grains or buried surface hoar, which could be more than 2.5ft below the surface. This past week, large, human triggered and natural avalanches have likely failed on buried surface hoar. You'll need to carefully evaluate the snowpack to travel safely in avalanche terrain at all elevations. Open slopes from north to southeast aspects and steeper than 30 degrees will be the most likely areas to trigger one of these.

Surface hoar tends to survive in open, sheltered and shaded terrain. so you could trigger slides even below treeline on convex, and unsupported features. At mid elevations and further east, instabilities within or below a deteriorating rain crust from January could produce persistent slabs with the additional new snow and wind on Saturday. When the snowpack is this complex, keep your terrain choices simple.

media.caption: (2/3/2021) A ski triggered avalanche was reported in Portley Bowl on 2/2. The next day an observer took the bottom photograph at 10:50AM. The majority of the rest of the slopes in the bowl had avalanched, with no ski tracks observed in or out of the slides. These may have been solar triggered, and suspected to have failed on a buried surface hoar layer from 1/30.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Persistent Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Persistent Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) in the middle to upper snowpack, when the bond to an underlying persistent weak layer breaks. Persistent layers include: surface hoar, depth hoar, near-surface facets, or faceted snow. Persistent weak layers can continue to produce avalanches for days, weeks or even months, making them especially dangerous and tricky. As additional snow and wind events build a thicker slab on top of the persistent weak layer, this avalanche problem may develop into a Deep Persistent Slab.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
Another round of new snow and strong westerly winds will transport the snow as it falls on Friday. Wind slabs could be quite reactive as they rest over a suncrust on solar aspects, and recently buried surface hoar on shaded aspects. Feel for wind stiffened or hollow sounding snow as you enter open areas, and change aspects. Be especially careful of cross loaded gully features and cornices. Watch for shooting cracks or whumphing collapses as a clear sign of instability.  Wind slabs could also step down to other weak snow layers in the top 2ft of the snowpack.

Outside of wind affected areas, loose dry avalanches may run and entrain new snow on steep slopes. Don't let a small loose avalanche ruin your day by pushing you into terrain traps or strainers.

media.caption: Example wind slab: Long shooting cracks through wind stiffened snow are direct signs of instability.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wind Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wind Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) formed by the wind. Wind typically transports snow from the upwind sides of terrain features and deposits snow on the downwind side. Wind slabs are often smooth and rounded and sometimes sound hollow, and can range from soft to hard. Wind slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

146.author: Matt Primomo
146.bottom_line: Another round of snowfall with very strong wind will create very dangerous avalanche conditions at upper elevations on Saturday. A number of close calls have occurred with large and often surprising avalanches on a slick crust from mid-January, and avalanches could be 4ft deep in wind affected areas. Travel in avalanche terrain at upper elevations is not recommended, and consider avoiding steep, open slopes below treeline.
146.hazard_discussion:
Another storm is rolling through the Cascades with some very strong winds along with it. Just as important for avalanche conditions as the new snow will be the extremely strong winds, which can transport snow 10x faster than it can fall out of the sky. The storm will favor areas closer to the crest such as the Salmon la Sac, but won't produce as much snow as last weekend's storms for places like the Wenatchee Mountains. 

Observers reported a natural D2 avalanche on an east aspect at 5,500ft west of Blewett Pass on Friday. This appeared to have run on the deeper crust from mid-January. On Thursday, a snowboarder took a ride with a wind slab at Mission Ridge on a Northwest aspect in the Near Treeline elevation band. Luckily they escaped unharmed. An observer reported a number of large (up to D2.5) avalanches with the recent storm from February 1 or 2 near Holden Village. On Wednesday, Mission Ridge Ski Patrol reported 4 large hard slab avalanches with control work. These likely ran on the crust from 1/13, and were roughly 24"+ deep x 100ft wide in ridgetop, or near ridgetop terrain. Whumphing collapses such as the ones I experienced in low angle terrain near the summit of Mt Lillian on Tuesday continue to tell us that deeper weak layers are primed to avalanche. In all parts of the zone, weak structure can be observed in the top 2-3 feet of the snowpack, and could result in an avalanche. These include facets resting on a crust from mid-January, or a sandwich of crusts from that same time. At lower elevations, you'll find less new snow and a stronger recent rain crust. 

During the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, continue to follow the latest guidance from local, state, and federal health officials. Avoid unnecessary risks that could impact first responders and stress medical resources. Wear a mask when appropriate, practice social distancing, and consider recreating closer to home.

media.caption: (2/3/2021) This crack came from a whumph we heard while stepping on a thick wind pillow. It fractured on the slick 1/13 crust, about 1.5ft deep.
(2/2/2021)  A compression test shows an easy result failing top of the mid-January facet/crust combo.  NE aspect 6200' on Mt Lillian. Video by Matt Primomo
(2/2/2021) Ski triggered persistent slab near Chair 2 at Mission Ridge with a 48" crown. A bystander was caught and carried, no injuries reported.

(2/5/2021) This avalanche was remotely triggered in backcountry terrain just outside of the Crystal ski area. Similar to other recent slides, it failed on facets just above the 1/13 crust. 60cm deep, 150' wide. 5200' ESE aspect. Photo: Crystal Mt Ski Patrol
(2/2/2021) The result from an extended column test indicates propagation is possible on an East aspect at 5900 ft.  ECTP11 down 40 cm on 1/13 facet/crust combo. Photo by Matt Primomo
(2/2/2021) About 4 inches of fresh snow coats the SE side of Mt Lillian. Photo by Matt Primomo

(1/28/2021) A quick profile at the site of a large collapse with cracks running 10 feet through the snow. A thick weak layer of facets can be seen just under a crust and recent snow that fell since the 24th. Icicle drainage, NW, 6,900ft. Photo: Josh Hirshberg
(1/27/2021) Profile showing weak structure with a crust facet sandwich.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
The new snow and strong wind will increase the chances for triggering avalanches 2ft to 4ft deep. Persistent slabs can propagate widely across terrain features and can result in large and deadly avalanches. Travel in or under avalanche terrain at upper elevations is not recommended on Saturday. Stay well out from underneath any large open slopes steeper than 30 degrees, as they can be triggered in surprising ways from below. Be alert to signs of instability such as shooting cracks, and whumphing collapses.

Recent observations continue to indicate that large, hard slab avalanches can release on a crust from mid-January. These have occurred mainly on Northwest to Southeast aspects above 5,500ft. The Salmon la Sac, Icicle, and other areas on the western edge of the zone are the places that are most likely to be very dangerous on Saturday. The Wenatchee Mountains east of Hwy 97 will continue to have these dangerous conditions as well. When the snowpack is this complex, keep your terrain choices simple. Elevations below 4,500ft may offer significantly lower chances of triggering one of these.

media.caption: (2/3/2021) This natural avalanche likely occurred overnight on 02/02. Similar to other slides in the East Central, it failed on facets above the 1/13 crust in non-skier compacted terrain of Crystal Mt. It occurred on a SE aspect at 6500'. Crown depth 2'. Photo: Crystal Mountain Ski Patrol

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Persistent Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Persistent Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) in the middle to upper snowpack, when the bond to an underlying persistent weak layer breaks. Persistent layers include: surface hoar, depth hoar, near-surface facets, or faceted snow. Persistent weak layers can continue to produce avalanches for days, weeks or even months, making them especially dangerous and tricky. As additional snow and wind events build a thicker slab on top of the persistent weak layer, this avalanche problem may develop into a Deep Persistent Slab.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: Extremely strong winds will transport the snow that falls in all open and exposed terrain on Saturday. Feel for wind stiffened or hollow sounding snow as you enter open terrain, and change aspects.  Any avalanche in the new snow could step down to deeper weaker layers and result in a very large and deadly avalanche above 5,000ft. Consider the terrain you're connected to and avoid steep, open wind loaded slopes. Stay alert to indicators of wind slab such as heavy snow drifting, shooting cracks and whumphing collapses. Small loose snow, or soft slab avalanches are possible on steep, sheltered slopes where more than 8" of new snow falls as well.

media.caption: (2/1/2021) From White Pass on Monday: Example of a small wind slab avalanche stepping down to weaker deeper layers.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wind Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wind Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) formed by the wind. Wind typically transports snow from the upwind sides of terrain features and deposits snow on the downwind side. Wind slabs are often smooth and rounded and sometimes sound hollow, and can range from soft to hard. Wind slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

147.author: Dallas Glass
147.bottom_line: Very strong winds transported fresh snow into firm windslabs which may have developed in unusual locations and further downslope than typical. In some areas, avalanches could break into older snowlayers and produce large and deadly slide.
147.hazard_discussion:
A moderate storm impacted the East South area, with significant winds and a few inches of new snow Friday--a pattern that will repeat Saturday. You could trigger avalanches in places where the winds drift the snow into deeper slabs. Blowing snow may serve as your simplest observations to identify wind loaded slopes. Drifts behind objects and changes in the depth of soft snow may also help you pick out potential trouble spots. Strong westerly winds could form slabs on exposed features at any elevation. 

We don’t know much about the snowpack structure of the East South area. However, all other zones in the Washington Cascades show persistent slabs in their forecasts (West South Forecast, East Central Forecast). A safe bet will be to assume that persistent weak layers exist at least in some parts of this region too. In most areas, weak facets sit above a very thick and prominent mid-Janurary crust (1/13). These sugary grains failed in avalanches in both adjacent zones (East Central and West South). While you can use snow profiles and snowpack tests to find and monitor these layers, don’t risk your life based on one hole in the snow. Avalanches are most likely to fail on persistent grains underneath wind loaded pockets. As a result, give all steep wind-loaded slopes a very wide berth. If you dig in the snow, help us find and track these potentially dangerous layers by submitting an observation. 

At lower elevations, a thin snowpack still exists in many locations. Shallowly buried obstacles, open creeks, and bare ground may block your path. The snowpack should increase dramatically as you ascend in elevation and get closer to the crest. 

During the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, continue to follow the latest guidance from local, state, and federal health officials. Avoid unnecessary risks that could impact first responders and stress medical resources.  Wear a mask when appropriate, practice social distancing, and consider recreating closer to home.

media.caption: (2/1/2021) This snow profile from Miriam creek near White Pass shows the facet layer of concern.
(1/27/2021) Profile showing weak structure with a crust facet sandwich.

(1/28/2021) A skier intentionally triggered this avalanche (D2) in Icicle Creek on a north aspect at 3800ft that entrained soft snow and ran several hundred feet. The avalanche likely ran on the most recent (1/14) crust and associated weak snow (facets or surface hoar). East Central Zone
(2/1/2021) This small wind slab avalanche stepped down to the 1/23 facets above the thick prominent crust. Gunsight Bowl: N aspect, 6300',  18" crown. HS-ASc-D1.5-R2-O

(2/3/2021) This natural avalanche likely occurred overnight on 02/02. Similar to other slides it failed on facets above the 13 crust in non-skier compacted terrain of Crystal Mt. It occurred on a SE aspect at 6500'. Crown depth 2'. Photo: Crystal Mountain Ski Patrol

148.author: Robert Hahn
148.bottom_line: Extreme winds Friday formed firm wind slabs further downslope than typical and in unusual locations. Minimize your exposure to avalanches by navigating around terrain features and start zones over 35 degrees.
148.hazard_discussion:
Mt Hood Meadows Pro Patrol reported a stabilizing upper snowpack on Thursday and largely wind-swept start-zones on Friday. Eastern slopes and higher elevations warmed significantly Friday, but steady wind kept the snow surface from warming to the point of loose wet avalanches. You may find a thin temperature or light "mist" crust on southerly aspects extending up to 7000 ft. 

The stout mid-January crust is considered the new "ground" with a strong snowpack structure in place below this layer. Weak and faceted snow just above the stout rain crust was responsible for a number of avalanches last week, but no new evidence of avalanches on this interface suggests these facets are gaining strength. 

During the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, continue to follow the latest guidance from local, state, and federal health officials. Avoid unnecessary risks that could impact first responders and stress medical resources.  Wear a mask when appropriate, practice social distancing, and consider recreating closer to home.

media.caption: Blowing snow, firm and textured snow, and cornice formation are all evidence that wind slabs are likely to be forming on lee slopes.
(1/16/21) Tilley Jane trail: At lower elevations, travel hazards may be lurking under the new snow.
(1/17/2021) Prior to the new snow, slopes like the one pictured here in Newton Canyon were deceptively icy. Debris from a very large (D3) wet avalanche last week can be seen in the valley bottom.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
Strong to extreme winds built firm wind slabs in unusual locations. Typical start zones may be wind-swept, but if you find a pocket of wind accumulated snow, it is likely to be large, firm, and difficult to escape in exposed terrain. Seek wind-sheltered terrain where possible. Avoid areas of active snow transport and wind-loading. Pay attention to cracking snow surfaces and firm, punchy layering. Avoid wind-loaded slopes steeper than 35 degrees, especially midslope convexities and shallow ridges.

Below treeline, slabs may be smaller, softer, and easier to steer around if you can identify the subtle, stiffer slab or find 8" of fresh snow. In either case, keep your slope angle below 35 degrees and avoid convex rollovers.

media.caption: Blowing snow, firm and textured snow, and cornice formation are all evidence that wind slabs are likely to be forming on lee slopes.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wind Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wind Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) formed by the wind. Wind typically transports snow from the upwind sides of terrain features and deposits snow on the downwind side. Wind slabs are often smooth and rounded and sometimes sound hollow, and can range from soft to hard. Wind slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.
